Sam Altman, the co-founder and CEO of OpenAI, has emerged as one of the most influential figures in the world of artificial intelligence (AI). As the driving force behind one of the most groundbreaking AI research companies, Altman has set a precedent for technological innovation and responsible development. In this article, we explore the key stages of Sam Altman's life and career, which have contributed to his ascension as a transformative leader in the AI space.

Sam Altman’s Foundational Years & Schooling

Sam Altman was born in Chicago in 1985 but relocated to the suburbs of St. Louis, Missouri, during his childhood. Demonstrating a keen interest in numbers and computers from a young age, Altman exhibited remarkable aptitude in these areas. [...] Sam Altman's journey from a college dropout to the CEO of one of the most impactful AI companies in the world is a testament to his relentless pursuit of innovation and his commitment to responsible technological progress. As the leader of OpenAI, Altman continues to shape the future of artificial intelligence and its potential to improve the lives of people worldwide. [...] In a world where technology is advancing at breakneck speed, the creation of artificial general intelligence (AGI) has become an increasingly pressing concern. Recognizing the potential risks that AGI could pose to humanity, two visionary entrepreneurs, Sam Altman and Elon Musk, decided to take matters into their own hands. Their collaboration led to the founding of OpenAI, a groundbreaking nonprofit organization on a mission to safeguard humanity from the unintended consequences of AGI.

## Who Is Sam Altman?

Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, is one of the leading proponents of artificial intelligence in the world. Raised in St. Louis, Altman dropped out of college before founding social mapping company Loopt and launching a career as a venture capitalist. He co-founded OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT, in 2015 with Elon Musk and others and became CEO in 2019. He remains in this role despite the company’s decision to briefly remove him in 2023. In addition to his work in AI, Altman is a successful investor and one of the richest people in the world thanks to stakes in companies such as Reddit and Stripe.

## Early Life and Family

Samuel Harris Altman was born on April 22, 1985, in Chicago. He primarily grew up in St. Louis after his family moved there during his childhood.

Sam’s mother, Connie Gibstine, works as a dermatologist, while his father, Jerry Altman, was a real estate broker. Sam is the oldest of the couple’s four children; he has two brothers, Jack and Max, and a sister, Annie. According to New York Magazine, the close-knit family ate dinner together every night and bonded through games such as table tennis, billiards, and charades. The three Altman boys also played water polo.

data.title: Sam Altman to companies: Don't hire aggressively, so that you don't ...
data.snippet:
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has once again addressed how artificial intelligence (AI) will impact the workforce. The chief executive of the company behind the popular ChatGPT chatbot has warned companies against aggressive hiring after making AI-driven layoffs. He has advised companies to take a more cautious approach to workforce expansion as AI capabilities continue to advance.In a recently live-streamed town hall event (seen by Business Insider), Altman said, “What I think we shouldn't do, and what I hope other companies won't do either, is hire super aggressively, then realise all of a sudden AI can do a lot of stuff, and you need fewer people, and have to have some sort of very uncomfortable conversation. So I think the right approach for us will be to hire more slowly but keep hiring.” [...] Comments

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman advises companies against rapid hiring, citing AI's growing capabilities. He advocates for slower, deliberate workforce expansion to avoid difficult layoffs. Altman revealed OpenAI will significantly reduce its hiring pace, emphasizing increased productivity through AI, though no staff cuts are planned. This comes amid a broader hiring slowdown in the US.

data.title: Just finished reading the world's first biography of Sam Altman
data.snippet:
Seven years later, he has matured; his scholarly vibe has grown stronger, and he seems to have become even more introverted. From giving up his well-paying career (in software engineering) to becoming a journalist, he has found his passion after wandering around (I hear he still lives as a digital nomad now). He knows many Silicon Valley celebrities, but maintains independent thinking and a healthy skepticism of fame.

I can sense that we both admire the spirit of Silicon Valley: a pursuit of innovation (“better to be a pirate than join the navy”), a desire to make a difference, direct communication, and a disdain for certain mediocre, lumbering giants. [...] His motivations may still be up for debate, and I personally disagree with technological accelerationism, but it’s worth learning from his efforts to help people and unite them. Understanding that every individual is a complex being, striving to find people’s shining points, and bringing out their best — this is a valuable approach to both life and character. In comparison, my previous approach of “clear love and hate,” judging people in black and white, deserves some reflection. [...] Stay ambitious. Whether taking over Y Combinator (with some even saying “under Sam’s leadership, YC’s ambition increased tenfold”) or founding OpenAI in 2015, when Google and DeepMind were far ahead in AI, or the global vision mentioned earlier, Sam’s actions go far beyond what a typical founder would imagine or accomplish. I remember being surprised the first time I read about his “Moore’s Law of Everything” because it almost seemed like a political utopian manifesto. Whatever the case, he is indeed trying to do what he claims: “One big secret is that you can change the world largely according to your will. Most people haven’t even tried.”
